div.p: THE ENCHANTER; OR, LOVE and MAGIC.
THE ENCHANTER; OR, LOVE and MAGIC. A MUSICAL DRAMA.
As it is performed at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane. The MUSIC compoſed By Mr. SMITH.
LONDON: Printed for J. and R. TONSON, in the Strand. MDCCLX.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: AS the Recitative commonly appears the moſt tedious part of a Muſical Entertainment, the Writer of the following little Piece has avoided it as much as poſſible; and has endeavour'd to carry on what Fable there is, chiefly by the Songs.—The Reader is deſired to take notice, that the paſſages diſtinguiſhed by inverted commas, are omitted in the Repreſentation.

list.item: MOROC the Enchanter, by Mr. CHAMPNES.
KALIEL, Attendant Spirit, by Maſter LIONI.
ZOREB, contracted to ZAIDA, by Mr. LOWE.

body.head: THE ENCHANTER; OR, LOVE and MAGIC.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room in the Enchanter's Caſtle.

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: O Love, Deſtroyer Love, this Ravage ceaſe,
Or give me Conqueſt, or reſtore my Peace.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: The Hinds that whiſtle Care away,
The Birds that ſing, the Beaſts that play,
Shew what a Wretch I am!
" A Wretch of Reaſon and of Power,

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: O Kaliel! Kaliel! Speak thou faithful Slave,
What Hope?—Will Zaida yield?—Alas, I rave!

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: Torn from her Lover's Arms,—The mournful Fair,
Rejects your Vows, and cheriſhes Deſpair;
Like a tranſplanted Flower, the blooming Spoil,
Droops in a foreign, tho' a richer Soil.

sp.speaker: MOROC.
sp.l: Obdurate Fair-one! What uncommon Mould
Impreſs'd thy Mind—That Pleaſure, Power, nor Gold
Can ſoften or allure it;—Take this Wand;— [Gives a Wand to Kaliel.
Again perſuade,—implore,—at thy Command
Joys ſhall attend—While I with other Arms
My Rival ſeek, and Hell ſhall aid my Charms.

lg.l: Let your Spells her Fancy bind,
Thro' her Senſes reach her Mind.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A Garden belonging to the Enchanter.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Intruder Sleep! In vain you try
To huſh my Breaſt, and cloſe my Eye;
The Morning Dews refreſh the Flow'r,

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: O Let not Grief your Bloom deſtroy,
Youth's faireſt Bloſſoms ſpring from Joy,
And Beauty's Cheek with Tints ſupply,
Which nipt by Sorrow fade and die.
No Clouds ſhall ſhade the Day,
What's Life without Love, what Love without Thee?

lg.head: RECIT. Accomp.
lg.l: To Zaida's Ears thy Strains might ſweetly flow,
Had Zoreb's Air or Face her Boſom fir'd;
No tranſient Paſſion caught her Heart,—Oh, no!
Can Paſſion die, that Virtue has inſpir'd?

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Whate'er you ſay, whate'er you do,
My Heart ſhall ſtill be fix'd and true;
And rages there in Guſts and Storms;
But Love with us a conſtant Gale
Juſt ſwells the Sea, and fills the Sail;
Neither of Winds or Waves the Sport,
We rule the Helm, and gain the Port.

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: Ye Votaries of Mirth and Love,
In all your various Mazes move,
The happieſt Union known on Earth,
Is Mirth with Love, and Love with Mirth.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: LYSSA enters with her Followers, as the Votaries of Mirth and Love.

lg.l: And tho' the Tongue ſays, nay;

div.stage: [A Dance by the Followers of Lyſſa.

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: 'Tis thus we revel, dance and play,

sp.speaker: LYSSA.
sp.l: Would you taſte the Sweets of Love,
Ever change, and ever rove,
Fly at Pleaſure, and away.
Love's the Cup of Bliſs and Woe,
Nectar if you taſte and go,
Poiſon if you ſtay.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Would you taſte the Sweets of Love,
Never change and never rove,
Fly from Pleaſures that betray.
Love's the Cup of Bliſs, and Woe,
Poiſon if you taſte and go,
Nectar if you ſtay.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: ZAIDA, LYSSA, and other female Spirits following.

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: Shame of thy Sex—begone—nor haunt me more.

sp.speaker: LYSSA.

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: Will Zaida's Boſom from a Woman hide,
What to conceal from Man, is Art and Pride?
Behold! Power's ſovereign Charm to ſoften Hate,
What melts us moſt!—Variety and State!

sp.stage: [Waves her Wand, and the whole Scene and Decorations change.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Turn and ſee what Pleaſures woo you,
Let not Love in vain purſue you,
Seize his Bleſſings while you may,
Love has Wings and will not ſtay.

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Seize his Bleſſings whilſt you may,
Love has Wings, and will not ſtay.

lg.head: RECIT. Accomp.
lg.l: My Zoreb's ſtronger Spells to break;
For him alone I draw my Breath,
With him I could rejoice in Death.

div.stage: [It thunders, grows dark, and the Garden ſhakes, All the Women run off, but Zaida and Lyſſa.

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: 'Tis Paſt—the ſofter Paſſions take their Flight,
Moroc, comes arm'd in Terrors and in Night!
Deſtruction in his Eye, and in his Hand,
The Scepter of His Wrath—His Ebon Wand.

lg.head: RECIT. Accomp.
lg.l: No more I come with Sighs and Pray'is,
A proud ungrateful Fair to ſue:
A Feſtival for Love and you!

sp.speaker: LYSSA,
sp.l: O hear her Sighs, believe her Tears,
The Heart may change that pants with Fears. To Moroc.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Hear not my Sighs, nor truſt my Tears,
My Heart may pant, but not with Fears:
His Treaſure loſt, the Miſer mourns.

sp.speaker: LYSSA.
sp.l: More Treaſure found, his Joy returns.

sp.speaker: MOROC.
sp.l: Hence Jealouſy and love-ſick Cares!
Vengeance now my Boſom tears!

sp.speaker: LYSSA.
sp.l: " The Joys of Power will here attend thee!

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: " The Joys of Love with Zoreb ſend me!

sp.speaker: LYSSA.
sp.l: " With him your Heart new Woes would prove.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: " I fear no Woes with him I love.

lg.l: " Away with Love and fond Deſires—
" Vengeance rage with all thy Fires."

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: Lyſſa, depart!—this is no Hour for Joy,
I come not now to pity; but deſtroy— [Exit Lyſſa, &c.
To Zaida's Arms her Lover I reſign;
He's dead, and dying thought you mine,
For him alone you draw your Breath,
With him you ſhall rejoice in Death!

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A Tomb riſes from the Ground, in which ZOREB lies, KALIEL ſtanding by him with his Wand on his Breaſt.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.

lg.head: RECIT. Accomp.
lg.l: My Zoreb—dead!—then Sorrow is no more:
Now let the Lightning flaſh, the Thunder roar!

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Back to your Source weak, fooliſh, Tears,
Away, fond Love, and Woman's Fears;
The Dove ſhall ſoar with Eagle's Wing,
And fly to Heav'n, and Zoreb's Arms.

sp.stage: [Offers to ſtab herſelf; Moroc runs to prevent her, and in his Fright drops his Ebon Wand, which Kaliel takes up.

sp.speaker: MOROC.
sp.l: Hold, deſp'rate Fair— [Takes away the Dagger. No more will I employ
Love's ſofter Arts, but ſeize, and force my Joy. [Takes hold of her.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Help, heav'nly Pow'rs!

sp.speaker: MOROC.
sp.l: What Pow'r can Moroc fear?

sp.speaker: KALIEL.
sp.l: The Pow'r of Virtue—which I now revere!
With thy own Arms thy guilty Reign I end,
No longer Moroc's Slave, but Zaida's Friend.
Thus do I blaſt thee—As the Thunder's Stroke
Blaſts the proud Cedar—All thy Charms are broke.

div.stage: [Kaliel ſtrikes Moroc with the Wand, and he ſinks.

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: How ſhall I thank the Guardian of my Fame?[kneels to Kaliel.

sp.speaker: KALIEL.
sp.l: Riſe, Zaida!—Peace!—more thanks ſhall Kaliel claim.
Behold thy Zoreb dead to mortal View,
The Spells diſſolv'd, ſhall wake to Life, and you.

lg.head: RECIT. Accomp.
lg.l: This magic Wand, in Moroc's Hand
In Kaliel's Hand this magic Wand

div.stage: [While the Symphony is playing, Zoreb riſes gradually from the Tomb.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: " What Angel's Voice, what ſweet enchanting Breath
" Calls hapleſs Zoreb from the Bed of Death?
" But now I wake to Day,
" Too weak my Power's to bear this Flood of Light,
" For all Elyzium opens to my Sight."[looks rapturouſly on Zaida.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: O Zoreb!—O my Lord!—My boſom Gueſt!
Tranſport is mute! My Eyes muſt ſpeak the reſt.

sp.speaker: ZOREB.
sp.l: And do I wake to Bliſs, as well as Life!
'Tis more than Bliſs!—'tis Zaida—'tis my Wife.

sp.speaker: KALIEL.
sp.l: In Fate's myſterious Web this Knot was wove:
Thus Heaven rewards your Conſtancy and Love. [joins their Hands.

sp.speaker: ZOREB, ZAIDA.
sp.l: No Power could divide us, no Terror diſmay,
No Treaſures could bribe us, no Falſhood betray:
No Demons could tempt us, no Pleaſure could move,
No Magic could bind us, but the Magic of Love.

sp.speaker: ZOREB.
sp.l: The Spell round my Heart was the Image of You;
Then how could I fail to be conſtant and true?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: The Spell round my Heart was the Image of You;
Then how could I fail to be conſtant and true?

lg.head: RECIT.
lg.l: Hover round and guard this Pair:
Love and Virtue triumph here. [Waves his Wand.

lg.head: AIR.
lg.l: Ye Shepherds who pipe on the Plain;
Leave your Lambs and your Sheep,
Each Fiend of the Boſom deſtroy:

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: No longer united, no longer oppreſs:
For ever united, for ever ſhall bleſs.
